body:
Thank you for the testing!

On Tue, Feb 2, 2016 at 1:56 PM, Kamil notifications@github.com wrote:

> I have tried with the latest release (20160202) and still no success (had
> to revert back to the one that is working, i.e., 20151228). The problem
> starts with as simple command as
> mx.nd.ones(c(2,3), mx.gpu())
> which returns a matrix full of zeros instead of ones. By the way, the same
> erroneous behavior occurs with the windows version of python package build.
> Again, release 20151228 does not have this behavior.
> 
> Just for the reference, the other issues reported the same problem are:
> #1336 https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/1336, #1228
> https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/1228
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/1358#issuecomment-178757762.

## 

Qiang Kou
qkou@umail.iu.edu
School of Informatics and Computing, Indiana University
Happy to help!
@tqchen Could you have a quick look? I'll merge afterwards.

2

As a newbie to mxnet I sometimes feel too embarrassed to ask dumb question in Github/issues, fearing that I would visually block some more important issues happening in Github/issues. 

Also, 2 would be a nice place for people to showcase their pet projects using mxnet...  hopefully you can find good apps with great potential, who knows?
Can one of the admins verify this patch?
Can one of the admins verify this patch?

Some comments, this PR seems contains three different component
- What does eval_iter mean? seems this is an additional args introduced.
- The pickable for ccsgd looks good, however, would be great we can have a general solution for pickle all possible implementation of optimizer, maybe can be done through the way we store node parameters as dict
-  imdecode function, I am not quite sure why this need to be in here, instead of using imdecode from opencv python then convert to ndarray, in worst case, let us make this a part of plugin.

eval_iter limit the number of evaluation batches to run. I'll add doc.

opencv doesn't release GIL so no multi threaded decoding. And even with single thread, this is 2-5x faster than cv2.imdecode.
You probably need custom metric for multi label learning.
@piiswrong Would you please check the custom eval_metric for me (the last two pictures)?

Accuracy of 0 most likely means your metric is buggy. By chance it should be at least around 1/num_class.
Try debugging with pdb
I think ndarray.imdecode should be the default way of decoding images. I'm planning to add it to recordio.unpack
Since there seem renewed interest, let me just quickly point out that discourse and not disqus would better fit our needs. https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/976#issuecomment-166829156
LGTM
@antinucleon I think we should make lr_mult and wd_mult rely on names, not indexes. It's more natual.
It's still hard to say what happened without seeing VGG_FACE_deploy_src.prototxt
Look into cudnn_covlution-inl.h. It shows how to use CUDNN_MAJOR to determine cudnn version and activate different code.

103        from multiprocessing.pool import ThreadPool  
if ThreadPool just the same as  the normal thread pool ,why not use the normal thread pool?
@mli I will try cudnnv4

Thank you @tqchen ! It was exactly the problem you described. Here's the backtrace:

```
(gdb) bt
#0  0x0000003d39432925 in raise () from /lib64/libc.so.6
#1  0x0000003d39434105 in abort () from /lib64/libc.so.6

   from /home/liuyz/dmlc/fork/mxnet/scala-package/native/linux-x86_64/target/libmxnet-scala.so
```

Seems that we ought to catch exceptions at 
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/engine/threaded_engine.cc#L292 and https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/engine/naive_engine.cc#L99 ?
I'm re-running the travis CI to see what happens.

These executions are asynchronize, so catch need to be added to places where the function is executed, instead of places where function is added to the queue. For NaiveEngine it is here https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/engine/naive_engine.cc#L87
The two places you point out pushes the function to the queue without executing them
Please make a fix and you are more than welcomed to open  a PR on this

Let us at least put imencode in a separate file, and try to minimumly add in python side. While this can be an offical part of the package, it is great if this can be isolated as a plugin module(that will be included by default) to make the code less coupled
I see. I'll fix and test it once I've got time today.

Python side wrapper is necessary because ndarray function interface only support float arguments and doesn't have default arguments.
Plus putting the code somewhere else is going to make it even harder to find where things are defined.
@GravApple https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/1408 added this feature. You are welcome to test it.
@pevnak https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/1408 added this feature. You are welcome to test it.
@starimpact https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/1408 added this feature. You are welcome to test it.

Please add a few test cases on this, also suggest the following improvments.
- Make executor take a shared_ptr of the StorageAllocator (this helps cleanup the code reference issue).
- Being able to call release and re-aquire space during runtime, so an executor can optionally release its requested memory, and re-aquire it during imperative execution (optional, can do it later).

I thought about sharing StorageAllocator at the start, but that actually doesn't work. Suppose ExecA has 2 chunks of memory, Rebind ExecB reuse 1 chunk and allocate 1 new chunk. Then ExecA destructs. Now The un-reused 1 chunk of memory stays there until all derived executors are deleted.
Understand this case, however, I guess the point of shared memory execs is that all the shared execs destructs together. We can discuss a bit on this offline

Not really. Usually you have one base exec. Then for each batch you derive a new exec with different size. After this batch the new exec destructs. Then if it allocated any new memory they will stay there unused before base destructs.
@tqchen Done. Lets do a final pass and merge this.
What does your trianing script look like and what error are you seeing?

Could you try tuning the workspace size for convolutional layers? If it's too much trouble setting it for each layer in python, just change the default value in C++ code.
My guess is setting it smaller will be better

hi stephen

many thanks for the feedbacks. correct me if i'm wrong, the main question you asked is why there are n different models even using synchronized training, e.g. `dist_sync`.

the answer is that all parameters expect for the batch normalization layer should be identical. the problem for the batch normalization is that it maintains a guess of the mean and variance of the gradient, which is correlated to the local data that node seem. we didn't do a synchronization between nodes to average their values during training. 

as a results, we have several different models at the end even for `dist_sync`. we can either pick one of them, or do a model average. we will be very appreciated if you have a better idea.

pretty standard one.
data is loaded with `mx.io.ImageRecordIter`
the Inception_BN is fine-tuned using `Feedforward.fit`
And the log shows that

```
[3108734.905849] Out of memory: Kill process 10617 (python) score 195 or sacrifice child
[3108734.907546] Killed process 10617 (python) total-vm:147094076kB, anon-rss:15868116kB, file-rss:344944kB
```

My desktop has 3 titanX cards and 32 GB memory (but only 16 GB free for training)

Thank you for your very speedy response. However, I suggest we try to make the situation better. I assume that my high level understanding of how the dist-sync process works is essentially correct, given that you made no corrections, so I'm continuing with this in mind.
1. Your response suggests that the user deploy an ensemble if they trained with a distributed net (perhaps only in the case if batch norm was used in the model design??). Thus if they trained over 28 nodes, e.g., you are recommending they deploy an ensemble of 28 models, so they can average the predictions of each? And thus, the more nodes they use in training, the worse the deployment to a run-time application becomes? As I stated in my original post, the mechanisms by which we train the model would ideally not effect the deployment/usage/interpretation of that model. I suppose we could always advise the user to simply pick the final model with the highest validation score, but then why not automate this to produce the final model?
2. If you know that the batch norm layer will create extra effort/issues on behalf of the users, I suggest that this should be pointed out clearly in the documentation and tutorials. I suggest the distributed training docs/tutorials should not end at: "yay! It ran to completion!", but rather: "now that training is completed, here's how we deploy the model to perform prediction on new images".
3. Why not allow the batch norm params to be synchronized, at least as an option? The normalization would be better, it would seem, if it were generalized across the entire training set by communicating each node's normalization stats to the PS and then aggregating and updating.
4. Even if the above is not advisable, how about at the very end of the process, we aggregate the batch norm values for use in the final model for run-time prediction? After all, the idea is to use statistics over the entire training corpus as an estimate to help us center new/unseen data. The more data the normalization stats are derived from, the better it should generalize. (I guess this simply restates the previous point, but makes the concession that maybe we aggregate the BN stats only at the very end, if for some reason, that's much preferred for accuracy or speed reasons.)
5. Finally, I interpret your answer that if I had no batch-norm in my deep net design, then I should observe identical validation scores at each epoch in the distributed training, and that my K final models would in fact be identical, so picking any one as the final model would suffice. (I will test this and see if this assertion holds).
Bilinear upsampling is implemented via convolution, therefore the weights. If you don't want them to be modified by training you need to set lr_scale to 0 for them.
When does this happen? At the start of training or after a while?
imagerecorditer definitely own't load the entire record file into memory. This should be caused by something else

At the beginning of the training.
But I find that the training takes more then 10 GB memory beside graphic memory.
So what's the usage of that part of memory 
( My batch size is 384, when I switch to 256, it get killed after one epoch)

Update,
I upgrade the memory and now the traning won't get killed.
And I just wondering when the training will take so much memory (17GB)

On the batchnorm question, the statistics on batchnorm is only needed at prediction time, and it is not part of model parameters used during training, the related parameters are synchronized. 

So the batchnorm only need to be aggregated once after the training is done

So it works like standard bilinear interpolation if I dont do weights update? Could you explain if I do update the weights, what will change? I ask this because I think bilinear interpolation is somehow a fixed method.

my answers to your comments:
1. a postprocessing to average the models into a single one will work. or even simply pick one model should be good enough. for large datasets such as imagenet, the model variance is not so big
2. can you help clarify the document?
3. refer to tianqi's comments
4. that should work, i think we already have a such script @antinucleon 
5. yeah. i tested that months ago. if you cannot repeat it then there should be a bug

If you update the weights it is trianed like a deconvolution layer, which
may be better than static bilinear upsampling.
On Feb 3, 2016 5:14 PM, "AsCu" notifications@github.com wrote:

> So it works like standard bilinear interpolation if I dont do weights
> update? Could you explain if I do update the weights, what will change? I
> ask this because I think bilinear interpolation is somehow a fixed method.
> 
> â€”

I did not find the corresponding documentation. I found Xavier, Normal, Uniform and so on. Would you tell me how to do it specifically. I suggest you could add this to the document.
In my problem, I assume I know the number of labels (say k). For evaluation metric, I check the largest k probability of the softmax layer and see if they match the ground truth labels.

```
import mxnet as mx
import numpy as np

from PIL import Image
#upsample filter
def upsample_filt(size):
    factor = (size + 1) // 2
    if size % 2 == 1:
        center = factor - 1
    else:
        center = factor - 0.5
    og = np.ogrid[:size, :size]
    return (1 - abs(og[0] - center) / factor) * \
           (1 - abs(og[1] - center) / factor)


#network
net = mx.symbol.Variable('data')
net = mx.symbol.UpSampling(net, scale=2, sample_type='bilinear', num_args = 2, name="up")

#image data
im  = Image.open("a.png")
im_data = np.array(im, dtype=np.float32)
im_data = np.swapaxes(im_data, 0, 2)
im_data = np.swapaxes(im_data, 1, 2)
im_data = np.expand_dims(im_data, 0)
im_data = mx.nd.array(im_data)
#upsampling weights
filt = upsample_filt(4)
initw = np.zeros((3,1,4,4), dtype=np.float32)
initw[range(3), 0, :, :] = filt
initw = mx.nd.array(initw)
#forward
c_exec = net.bind(ctx=mx.cpu(), args={'data': im_data, 'up_weight': initw})
c_exec.forward()
```

**I ran into an error "Floating point exception: 8". The above is the minimum working code. I am not sure it is because of the UpSampling itself or I missed something. Could you check into this?**

`net = mx.symbol.UpSampling(net, num_filter=3, scale=2, sample_type='bilinear', num_args = 2, name="up")`
You need to set num_filter to the number of channels. This is a nuisance due to a hacky solution. I'll try to find time to fix this.

> > Follow up to my original observation 2 -- k final models are different

After the training using LeNet completed, I tested each of the three saved models on the validation data and confirmed that they do produce the exact same output, so the final models are identical. Thus the usage of batch norm is indeed the culprit for my earlier observation, and with no batch norm, all is well.

> > Follow up to discussion on synchronizing batch norm

When we load the params file, there are "arg params" and "aux params". I believe the batch norm parameters are found in the "aux params", correct? Is it a true statement that any aux_params will NOT be synchronized by the parameter server, and thus will cause differences between the distributed models during the training process?

@tqchen, why not synchronize the batch norm variables during training? The paper that introduced the batch norm procedure didn't discuss what to do in the case of distributed training, but it would seem that if we shared the parameters during learning across the nodes that we'd have a better estimate at each learning stage from which to center the data. Since we are using data parallelism, and each of k nodes only sees 1/k of the data, especially when k is large, wouldn't we need to share the data statistics across the nodes in order to not have poorly estimated values at some of the nodes?

The problem is delete invokes an destructor, which cannot throw exception out. That is why this happened.

So the solution intended was always call r->Release() and catch exception there, so delete r won't call Release() again(note that there is a nullptr check in Release) can you look into what happened here?

I guess it might due to some problems in delete r still invokes the free

- The shared parameters of batch norm are synchronized during training.
- The moving mean variance statistics are NOT part of batchnorm parameters and will not affect training step, they are only used during test prediction

There is a prefetcher buffer in mxnet. MXNet of course won't load the entire dataset into memory, but this could due to too large prefetcher buffers.  Try change the prefetch_buffer parameter here http://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/python/io.html

Since there are multiple places where prefetching, and multi-threaded decoding is  happening. Some of them are not yet configurable. e.g.

https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/io/iter_image_recordio.cc#L324

@piiswrong can you confirm the memory consumption on your side normally as well?
Another option is to simply try mshadow::FreeSpace catch ... in ~TensorContainer()

Oh, nice catch, in general we should try catch in release, let us simply
set the ptr to nullptr after calling release in mxnet

Hi All,

I see that the issue is closed. I would want to try out the nccl as it has optimizations for IBM power. Also, the current code base is well optimized for intel and only hope of scaling on power platforms is to use nccl. The numbers I get while running train_cifar10.py are: 513 samples/sec, 575 samples/sec, 664 samples/sec and 739 samples/sec for one, two, three and four gpus. As you can see, it is scaling pretty badly.

i think you can manually merge that PR and have a try. the main problem is that nccl is quite buggy at that time i tested. also confirmed by other platform developers, nccl didn't improve things too much on most cnns

the reason you see different validation acc during training is because each node only runs validation on a part of the validation data. assume there are n nodes, we partition validation data into n parts, node i only report the results on part i.
i did a comparison between v3 and v4 on inception 7 using 4 x titan x. my results show v4 is still a little bit faster than v3.

So, can I just do a pull of that commit? I can pick them up from the browser but better would be to generate a patch and then try applying it. If something doesn;t apply automatically, I can manually do it.

For IBM systems, nccl has some good optimizations that may benefit. Dont know about stability..I tried just the benchmarks and they seem to run at a reasonable performance..can improve the low scaling I am seeing. Not sure on intel as I have access to only one GPU system

amithr

@piiswrong:
I have been trying to do a bit of investigating. My best guess as to what is going on is a race in when the lua garbage collector that is only getting triggered because an operator needs the output of two criterion.

I did a small test of putting a collectgarbage("collect") call into sharedserialize.lua save and load functions just before the return. This does create a reproducible segfault.

I am not sure why this is happening but is a problem.

cudnn v4:
workspace 128: 53 img/sec
workspace 256: 31 img/sec
workspace 512: 15 img/sec
workspace 1024: 16 img/sec

cudnn v3:
workspace 128: 53 img/sec
workspace 256: 50 img/sec
workspace 512: 51 img/sec
workspace 1024: 51 img/sec

I find it very strange how different the performance is from v3 to v4, but for now my issue is fixed with workspace.

Cudnn is being stupid and when allowed more workspace, picks an algorithm
thats both slow and memory consuming. We are going to change default
workspace to a smaller value to circumvent this.
